citations.narrative:
The facility has a written Program of Veterinary care as required, but the Program does not contain a schedule for
sampling of blood parasites as required; the field reads only, "Not currently an issue".
Parasites are a common cause of disease in dogs and can lead to serious illness and even death if not detected and
properly treated. The facility must have and follow a complete program of veterinary care, approved by the attending
veterinarian, which includes plans for sampling and any required treatment for blood and intestinal parasites. The missing
information must be added to the program of veterinary care to ensure the animals are receiving adequate veterinary
care. The facility must keep veterinary records that document vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs
(including rabies, parvovirus and distemper) and sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests (including fleas,
worms, coccidia, giardia and heartworm) in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian; records
should include results of all diagnostic testing.
TO BE CORRECTED BY 01/06/2026

There is inadequate shelter inside the primary enclosure of an adult, female bald eagle. The bird's enclosure has a solid
roof and three sides, but one entire side is constructed of only wire, and there are no objects that can serve as effective
barriers to provide options for the bird to escape wind, rain and snow that blow into the enclosure from that side.
Failure to provide adequate shelter from the environment can have serious detrimental effects on animal comfort, health
and well-being. The licensee must provide shelter and protection for each bird from climatic and environmental conditions
that may be detrimental to its health and well-being.
TO BE CORRECTED BY 12/31/2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility has a written Program of Veterinary care as required, but the Program does not contain a schedule for 
sampling of blood parasites as required; the field reads only, "Not currently an issue". 
Parasites are a common cause of disease in dogs and can lead to serious illness and even death if not detected and 
properly treated. The facility must have and follow a complete program of veterinary care, approved by the attending 
veterinarian, which includes plans for sampling and any required treatment for blood and intestinal parasites. The missing 
information must be added to the program of veterinary care to ensure the animals are receiving adequate veterinary 
care. The facility must keep veterinary records that document vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs 
(including rabies, parvovirus and distemper) and sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests (including fleas, 
worms, coccidia, giardia and heartworm) in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian; records 
should include results of all diagnostic testing.  
TO BE CORRECTED BY 01/06/2026 
3.153(a)(1)(vi) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
There is inadequate shelter inside the primary enclosure of an adult, female bald eagle. The bird's enclosure has a solid 
roof and three sides, but one entire side is constructed of only wire, and there are no objects that can serve as effective 
barriers to provide options for the bird to escape wind, rain and snow that blow into the enclosure from that side. 
Failure to provide adequate shelter from the environment can have serious detrimental effects on animal comfort, health 
and well-being. The licensee must provide shelter and protection for each bird from climatic and environmental conditions 
that may be detrimental to its health and well-being. 
TO BE CORRECTED BY 12/31/2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
 n
